_exec_summary.SummaryText:
AP is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release and/or fire, and subsequent implementation of notification procedures. 

The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated annually with the Selma Fire Department and Johnston County Department of Emergency Services.  Notification exercises are also completed annually.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Marathon continually strives to make Selma West Oak Street Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote a process safety culture, employees complete multiple PSM and RMP related education events along with establishing regular terminal representative meetings and maintaining consistent communication with its butane business partner.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

MPLX Terminals, LLC (Marathon)- Selma West Oak Street Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Selma West Oak Street Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Selma, NC. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, No. 2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum-based additives.

The Selma West Oak Street Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Selma West Oak Street Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that the Terminal has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances,
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs,
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals,
D. An overview of the emergency response program, and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The butane blending process has been classified as Program level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammab

le effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions while handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the threat to employee health, and minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety systems incorporated into the design of the process.  Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Selma West Oak Street Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in two (2) pressure vessels.  The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid, analyzers, and PLC.  Process safety controls include vessel pressure relief valves (PRVs), vessel internal excess flow valves, fusible elements (<250 degrees Fahrenheit) fail-safe emergency shutoff valves (ESVs), fill shutoff on the vessels, manual emergency shut-off devices (ESDs) throughout the process and on the video display terminal, pipe hydrostatic pressure reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Selma West Oak Street Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

Marathon's accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by regulated substances to its employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68 (enforcement has been delegated to the State of North Carolina), as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident preve

ntion program elements are in place at the Selma West Oak Street Terminal:

1) Employee Participation,
2) Process Safety Information,
3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA),
4) Operating Procedures,
5) Safety, Operations, and Maintenance Training,
6) Contractor Safety Management,
7) Pre-startup Safety Review,
8) Mechanical Integrity (Inspection, Testing, and Preventative Maintenance),
9) Hazardous (including Hot Work) Work Permits,
10) Management of Change,
11) Incident Investigation Procedures (including Process Safety Events),
12) Emergency Response/Action Plans,
13) Compliance Audits, and
14) Trade Secrets.

These fourteen (14) individual elements of the prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Marathon and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, the Selma West Oak Terminal also has specific prevention measures that are employed as part of its operating procedures along with engineering and administrative controls to prevent, identify, and contain/control a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:

General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures

-Engineering and construction in accordance with recognized industry and corporate standards,
-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety relief valves, etc.),
-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrumentation Diagrams and Process/Block Flow Diagrams,
-Operating systems monitored and controlled by trained Operators (both on-site and remotely),
-Computerized monitoring and automate process controls,
-Redundant control systems with an uninterruptable power supply,
-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems,
-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, and safety devices,
-Controlled facility access,
-Regular safety meetings and safety awareness programs,
-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits, and 
-Frequent unit surveillance by operators.

G

eneral Release Mitigation

-Automatic and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity,
-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks,
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release along with initiating a process and facility shutdown,
-Deluge system installed in offload area, and
-Fire water monitors installed near butane storage vessels.

General Emergency Response

-Emergency alert system,
-Periodic emergency training for employees,
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies,
-Emergency drills with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies,
-Mutual Aid with Local Fire Departments, and
-Participation with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) or its equivalent.

Further, the Selma West Oak Street Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, a "Smart Plan"/Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is in place with response activities coordinated with the Selma Fire Department and Johnston County LEPC.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Selma West Oak Street Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at its facility inclusive of root-cause analyses and follow-up actions, as appropriate. There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting in consequences as defined in the 40 CFR Part 68 reporting requirements.  The Terminal also tracks all process safety incidents per API 754 guidance.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Selma West Oak Terminal is identified as a "Non-responding Facility".  As previously noted, response actions are coordinated with the Selma Fire Department. A "Smart Plan"/ER
